This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

posts.com:
South Africa really is a microcosm of what the world will be like in barely a century.

Around 1868, blacks and whites were roughly at parity (50:50).

Alarmed by the British laissez-faire policies which were flooding historically white cities and the Cape Province with blacks, the National Party came to power in 1948, with a mandate to introduce apartheid in an attempt to stem the tide ("die verswarting van die platteland").

At this point, whites remained a majority within the historically white areas, but were already outnumbered 2:1.

By the time of the Soweto uprising, this ratio had become 7:1.

By the time De Klerk became State President and the 1992 referendum rolled around, this figure was more like 8:1 or 9:1.

Today, it is as high as 10:1, and the white population continues to decline. Whites make up 20% of the aged population, but no more than 6.5% of the youth population.

Among under 5s, whites represent no more than 4.7% of the population.

Now let's have a look at current overall African population growth, compared with that of Europe as a whole:

Now you might be thinking, "Don't worry Anon, there's no way that can be sustained!" but when you think about it, why not?

A black population crash was predicted in South Africa as early as the 1960s, but has yet to manifest itself. The productivity of South Africa's agricultural sector and the provision of basic medical care allowed the black population to soar, soar and then soar some more, to the extent that a single black city like Alexandra or Soweto now dwarfs the entire white population.

There is today only a single South African city with a white majority: Pretoria. Even there, the majority is razor-thin, and it will become black majority before long.

The Western Cape for the moment has a non-black majority, but that will go within a decade at the most.

I AM (Gr. ego eimi) is the divine Name of God in the OT, first revealed to Moses at the burning bush (Ex 3:13-15). John places special emphasis on the use of this Name to clearly reveal Christ as God. This divine claim illuminates Christ's authority even over death (v. 52), a power belonging only to God the Father.

Read the response I made for >>14451067. I already addressed what you just wrote.

Deification (Theosis) is the ancient theological word used to describe the process by which a Christian becomes more like God. St. Peter speaks of this process when he writes, “As His divine power has given to us all things that pertain to life and godliness . . . you may be partakers of the divine nature”.

What does it mean to partake of the divine nature, and how do we experience this? To give an answer, let us first address what deification is not, and then describe what it is.

What deification is not. When the Church calls us to pursue godliness, to be more like God, this does not mean that human beings become divine. We do not become like God in His nature. That would not only be heresy, it would be impossible. For we are human, always have been human, and always will be human. We cannot take on the nature of God.

St. John of Damascus makes a remarkable observation. The word “God” in the Scriptures refers not to the divine nature or essence, for that is unknowable. “God” refers rather to the divine energies—the power and grace of God that we can perceive in this world. The Greek word for God, theos, comes from a verb meaning “run,” “see,” or “burn.” These are energy words, so to speak, not essence words.

In John 10:34, Jesus, quoting Psalm 81:6, repeats the passage, “You are gods.” The fact that He was speaking to a group of hypocritical religious leaders who were accusing Him of blasphemy makes the meaning doubly clear: Jesus is not using “god” to refer to divine nature. We are gods in that we bear His image, not His nature.

Because of the Incarnation of the Son of God, because the fullness of God has inhabited human flesh, being joined to Christ means that it is again possible to experience deification, the fulfillment of our human destiny. That is, through union with Christ, we become by grace what God is by nature—we “become children of God” (Jn 1:12). His deity interpenetrates our humanity.

Historically, deification has often been illustrated by the example of a sword in the fire. A steel sword is thrust into a hot fire until the sword takes on a red glow. The energy of the fire interpenetrates the sword. The sword never becomes fire, but it picks up the properties of fire.

By application, the divine energies interpenetrate the human nature of Christ. When we are joined to Christ, our humanity is interpenetrated with the energies of God through Christ’s glorified flesh. Nourished by the Body and Blood of Christ, we partake of the grace of God—His strength, His righteousness, His love—and are enabled to serve Him and glorify Him. Thus we, being human, are being deified.

I don't claim to know if any one religion's idea of god is true but what makes the most sense to me (through my own fallible reason, subject to change) is this:
Things exist and operate on cause and effect, a chain of causes stretching back infinitely doesn't make sense, therefor there has to be something that's eternal and uncreated that set everything in motion.
The law of conservation of matter, the fact that physical things don't start or stop existing just change form, is a strong case against creation ex nihilo. This leads me to believe that if the first cause is god then everything that exists is a part of god and that he "creates" by acting upon himself.
Consciousness appears to be a fundamental property of the universe rather than arising from matter. Basically, there's no way to prove anything other than the fact that the mind exists, anything else is dependent on being observable by consciousness. If we assume (and I acknowledge that this is an assumption) that consciousness is a fundamental property of existence in the same way matter is then that would make god a conscious being and also solve the problem of an afterlife/reincarnation since consciousness wouldn't cease to exist.

The issue with defaulting to 'energy' as a basic substrate is the unwieldy nature of its primary meaning. What we refer to as 'energy' is but a abstraction representation of the innate capacity of action that a given object possesses, i.e. of something influencing or causing a change in something else in a noticeable, observable, or scientifically measurable way (usually in the form of motion, which is the most basic phenomena of observable). But this definition loses its very coherence when we start talking about quantum fields as vectors of influence overlapping one another in spacetime; the ontology ceases to be about 'things' in the material sense and becomes 'digital' in the sense that discrete units of information become the foundation of reality. The overlapping fields are analogous to layers or subsystems of a complex information processing system that, taken together, produces and interprets the content of reality (i.e. of the cosmos). This is pretty much what theoretical physicists, mathematicians, and software programmers spend all their day doing; establishing frameworks or structures for the interpretation of data, and working out the relationships that exist among quantities and qualities (i.e. variables) and how they interact to produce more complex variables and larger or smaller quantities, depending on the operation/interaction.

Now, as even a child can understand, the meaning of information, whether it is linguistic, numerical, or visual, is dependent on the context in which it is presented. 1+1=2 only insomuch as the addition of identical discrete quantities yields a greater quantity which is itself specified as the sum of its antecedents. What this means is that there are necessary preconditions in any information system in order for there to be data; the interpretative apparatus cannot 'emerge' or 'develop' alongside the data, but rather stands behind it and makes it intelligible. Thus, even an A.I. that can 'learn' in the sense that it can develop functions beyond that of the programmer's initial coding is still limited by the constraints of its interpretive nexus, and, hence, the amount of data it can act upon. There can be no 'new' data apart from the discrete units of information that were already present in the system as a baseline, as well as the varying ways of combining them to form larger structures of meaning, itself a process utterly reliant upon the 'architecture' or interpretative grid of the system.

But where does data (i.e. the content reality) come from in the first place? After all, I mentioned above that there can be no 'new' data in the sense of information introduced by the system itself (i.e the contextual framework of rules for interpreting reality) outside that which it has been initially supplied. Both data and the program which interprets it must themselves be necessarily supplied by an external source, who in everyday software production and maintenance we refer to as the programmer. It is he or she that both writes the program as well as supplies the basic units of code that serve as signals for the conveying of information.

This elaborate example depicts the main thrust of the contingency argument as presented in modern terms.

All this talk about "self-configuring", "self-processing", or "self-determining" reality simply proves what I had suspected early on: namely, that both you and Langan subscribe to a type of Spinozist monism. You assert that the prescriptive principle which organizes information and delimits meaning within reality is identical with the content of reality; the distinction, as you hold it, is a conceptual one rather than an actual one.

The problem with this view is that it conflates the order of being (the ordo essendi) with the order of knowing (the ordo cognoscendi). That is, you deny the logical and temporal priority of that which norms and delimits information as necessarily preceding that which it acts upon, or the modal entity that conveys or communicates information. The source always precedes the derivative; the cause always precedes the effect.

What Langan and his forebears (Liebniz, Fichte, Schelling, Hegel, Schopenhauer, and Bergson) believe is that consciousness and the volition exercised by rational agents is ultimately what is determinative of reality; the cosmos and its contents are self-interpreting closed system. The issue with this is that the irreversibility of numerous physical processes, as well as the degradation of information coherence and structure over time (i.e. entropy), necessarily disproves it. The universe, just like a software program, displays internal evidence of having a cause prior to and external to itself.

Just as mathematicians can alter the semantic and relational framework within which they examine quantities and variables by revising or replacing the terms (whether they be numerical values or operations therein performed as represented by symbols) that delineate meaning, so too can a programmer delimit and alter the possible meanings that data can possess within the context of the information processing system as a whole. Bottom line? Meaning is dependent or contingent upon a semantic network that precedes it

>>14444628
Gödel's incompleteness theorems are two theorems of mathematical logic that are concerned with the limits of provability in formal axiomatic theories. These results, published by Kurt Gödel in 1931, are important both in mathematical logic and in the philosophy of mathematics. The theorems are widely, but not universally, interpreted as showing that Hilbert's program to find a complete and consistent set of axioms for all mathematics is impossible. The first incompleteness theorem states that no consistent system of axioms whose theorems can be listed by an effective procedure is capable of proving all truths about the arithmetic of natural numbers. For any such consistent formal system, there will always be statements about natural numbers that are true, but that are unprovable within the system. The second incompleteness theorem, an extension of the first, shows that the system cannot demonstrate its own consistency.

Let me explain a bit further.

What caused the big bang?
Something. That's what.
Either it was a result of a previous universe that existed that collapsed or there is some other explanation.
It doesn't really matter.
Because whatever that is also has the same question of: what caused that to happen?
And this goes backwards an infinite number of times.
Everything is the result of a prior action.
Nothing can move on its own.
Except for some thing called a First Mover.
That first mover does not obey any logic we can conceive so far.
It doesn't obey any logic we can conceive of conceiving in the future.
It's illogical.
Yet it is also logical to think that something started all of this since we are here right now.
Unless time is a loop with no beginning or end.
But then: where did the loop come from?
From something outside time, and outside all logical notions of cause and effect.
A thing which should exist because here we are, but is utterly inscrutable to our minds.
That's a god.

>>14432409
From these pre-Incaic elements, the image could represent the ancient temple of Pachacamac, built in honor of the local god of the place, popular in much of the northern part of the Inca Empire, although the perspective seems more in line with the much larger and more recent Temple of the Sun built by the Incas.
The local non-Inca temple at Pachacamac was occupied by the Wari (among others), but when the Incas conquered the sactuary it was an Ichma temple and was painted with distinctive Ichma motifs (very diferent from Wari's), so it is also called the Painted Temple. In this temple survived a representation of the god Pachacamac, a wooden pole dating to the Wari period. As I said the Chavin were much older and all their sanctuaries and style had already been abandoned long ago, none surviving into the time of the Incas, not to mention that Chavin stone stelae are extremely rare and the few found are in the heart of Chavin, in its temple and nearby vicinity, not a single one has been found on the coast or so far away.

>>14432567
Knitting didn't exist in the pre-Columbian Andes, although they knew practically all other weaving techniques known today.

Similarly, ponchos appear to have been rare in comparison to today. Although they appear in some pre-Inca cultures (especially coastal ones) such as Paracas, for the most part they did not have the proportions of today's ponchos, the common attire of most highland provinces during the Inca empire was an uncu, which is a sleeveless tunic with a yacolla or blanket around it, which was still the common attire recorded in many parts in early colonial times, the rise in popularity of today's ponchos is rather hazy, but seems to have been an evolution of uncus from which the sides were left unstitched.

The native allies did not just let the spanish "step in". the spanish conquest is drastically simplified in school.

Native allies to the spanish did very well for themselves immediately after the destruction of tenochtitlan and fall of the inca empire. the main allies in mexico, the tlaxcalans, were independent, and simply existed as allies to the spanish, helping them in their further conquests in the area (keep in mind, they would continue fighting in mexico / central america until 1680 - the fall of the last independent mayan city). They received titles of nobility and enjoyed trade with the new spanish ports and mexico city. Other states like the purepecha realized that fighting the spanish and tlaxcalans and all their allies would be disastrous - so they agreed to be a vassal, which granted them much autonomy at the cost of paying tribute - not very dissimilar to what most polities near the aztecs were doing before the spanish arrived.

These powers quickly became irrelevant as disease continually decreased their population, while the spanish presence was growing incredibly quickly.

In peru, there was a similar situation in the sense that native allies were granted a lot of autonomy and access to trade, but were fucked over due to disease over time and eventually absorbed.

so native allies didn't just let themselves be repressed - generally speaking they gained in the short term from the conquest but lost in the long term, although there was not much they could do in that regard. allying with the spanish was not a bad idea knowing what they did

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I attempted praying to Mary and I would like to report my experience and thoughts on the matter, as it may be useful to someone. Recently I came around on some of the Marian dogmas and I thought that it might be beneficial to attempt praying to her, as this is such an important element of piety among Catholics and Orthodox. As a Protestant, when asking Christ for something, I will pray to him and make my request, then if it is not granted, I accept it, knowing that Christ knows what is best and that God wills things for my good. I don't generally make trivial requests, or ask for things like money -- normally I pray for strength regarding sinful temptations. But I had a pressing need regarding a the physical health of a family member, so I prayed to Christ asking that he would help them, and I prayed to Mary, and asked that she would also pray for this family member and ask Christ to help them. I did this on a number of occasions.

Suffice it to say that the prayer has not been answered in any observable way. That is acceptable, of course. I'm not evaluating this as some kind of experiment on whether my prayers will become more effective or something, but I wanted to see how this would affect my spirituality, or how I understand prayer. And I have to say that the change was strong, but in a wholly negative manner. Whereas in the past, I could make my petition, then accept Christ's will and move on, with the involvement of prayers to the saints this changes as there are now more possibilities. It could be that Christ will not grant the petition if I ask it, but he will grant it if Mary asks it ("the prayer of a righteous man avails much"). And perhaps Mary declined my request for prayer. In this case the way to get my prayer granted would be to supplicate Mary so that she might pray as I have requested.

(1/3)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Do you see the problem? Prayer becomes alienated from Christ and the acceptance of God's will, and becomes attuned to supplicating other humans, or creating the right conditions for your prayer to be accepted. This ties in with other concepts, like needing to pray in particular places, or pray in contact with or near the relics of saints, to increase the efficacy of prayer. It's almost like prayer ends up being more like constructing a spell, and it turns into a superstitious practice. Christ won't answer my prayer, but perhaps if I venerate Mary in my prayers enough, she will help me. Or perhaps if I pray near the bones of so-and-so he will pray for me and it will be sufficient. After all, we need the righteous to pray for us so that God will hear us. Simply asking him ourselves is not sufficient if we need something from Christ. That is the logic that comes to bear. It was at this point that I realized the importance of the Reformers fighting against this practice, and why they understood it as idolatry. Because it points us away from Christ and to other beings, to supplicate them instead of God.

(2/3)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
But the objection will be: what of James 5:16? Does not the prayer of the righteous have greater efficacy? Should we not seek out the righteous or (in Mary's case) the most righteous to pray for us? This verse gave me some consternation after my experience, but I eventually came to understand what it actually means. The verse in full:
>Confess your trespasses to one another, and pray for one another, that you may be healed. The effective, fervent prayer of a righteous man avails much.
Now the context is that he is telling the readers of the letter to pray for one another. So the prayers he is referring to are the ones performed by the readers of the letter. So who is the "righteous" whose prayers are so effective? Frankly, it is you. Or it is supposed to be you. If you are not righteous you need to demonstrate your faith through your works, as James tells us earlier in the letter. Rather than telling us to seek out the righteous to pray for us, he is telling us to pray for others, because our prayers can help them. The emphasis placed on this verse by Catholics and Orthodox is inverted from its meaning. James wants us to direct our prayers to the benefit of others, the Catholic and Orthodox reading is for us to seek out the prayers of others who are more righteous in order for our own prayers to be answered. See the difference? This is the meaning of Christians praying for each other, not that we seek out particular righteous people to pray for us in a superstitious way, because otherwise Christ may not hear us; but that we love each other and pray for each other, because we wish God to be merciful on all of us. If we love our brother in Christ, we ask God to bless him. To dig beyond this, to try to extrapolate this into a system of efficacy, is to torture the text and miss its entire point.

I repented of my prayers to Mary and I hope others who do this will repent as well.

(3/3)

>>14450454
>It can be more than a symbol and still not be literal.
The word "literal" is not correct from the Catholic perspective. Catholics speak of Christ's Body and Blood as being really, truly and substantially present, but it is not *literally* present, but rather sacramentally. This tension, or mystery, was there from the beginning, when Christ initiated the sacrament, holding a piece of bread in His hands and saying, "This is my body," although it yet appeared, still, after He (God) spoke those words, to be a piece of bread.

>Isn't eating blood forbidden for Christians?
When Jesus declared all foods clean (Mk 7:19), his command superseded the earlier command that certain foods be regarded as unclean (Lv 11:1-8). If Jesus today commands us to drink his blood, his command supersedes any prior command concerning drinking blood.

The command against drinking blood, like all of the Old Testament dietary regulations, has passed away, for “These are only a shadow of what is to come, but the substance belongs to Christ. Therefore let no one pass judgment on you in questions of food and drink” (Col 2:17, 16).

The mention of not eating blood in Acts 15:20, 29 was a pastoral provision suggested by James to keep Jews from being scandalized by the conduct of Gentile Christians. We know that these pastoral provisions were only temporary. One concerned abstaining from idol meat, yet later Paul says eating idol meat is okay so long as it doesn’t scandalize others (Rom 14:1-14, 1 Cor 8:1-13).

Source: https://www.catholic.com/qa/is-jesus-command-to-drink-his-blood-a-violation-of-gods-law

1. The civilizations there were not empires in the traditional sense as we recognized them in Eurasia. They were tributary states who subdued their neighbors but did not assimilate them to any state religion or culture. Such a society is not prone to expansion of its people or language.

2. The existing travel networks that connected to these city states were mostly inland waterways and navigated by canoe. There were no seaworthy ships and coastal fishermen mostly hugged the coast.

https://digitalcommons.tourolaw.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1079&context=jrge

From adolescence, black female slaves were subjected
to their master's desire for them to reproduce because increasing the
number of slaves resulted in an increase in profits.9 Whether it be
forceful or subtle, there were instances of sexual intervention that
occurred at the hands of the slave master.10
The physical as well as psychological struggles that came with
childbearing were enormous for enslaved women. They were expected
to put the needs of the master and his family before those of their own
children. The slave mothers on large plantations returned to the fields
soon after giving birth, leaving their child to be raised by others.11 On
a smaller plantation, the responsibilities of slave mothers were simply
added to their usual duties.12 Slave mothers often intentionally stayed
in bondage to avoid being separated from their child, while their male
counterparts attempted to escape.13 Tragically, the enslaved mothers
faced the possibility of witnessing their daughters suffer the same fate
of essentially being a breeder for the slave master.
In addition to being a slave breeder they were also the subjects
of experimental gynecological and reproductive surgeries, which were
often performed with no anesthesia.14 Some sources estimate that 58%
of all enslaved women aged 15–30 years old were sexually assaulted by
their slave owners and other white men.

Jezebel stereotype was particularly common during slavery, when
black women’s bodies were socially controlled as sexual objects based
on racist, classist, and sexist ideologies.24 Within the bounds of slavery,
masters often felt it was their right to engage in sexual activity with
enslaved black women.25 Sometimes, enslaved black women acquiesced
to advances hoping that such relationships would increase the chances
that they or their children would be liberated by the master.26

One interesting quirk of slave history in some places is that some slavemasters gave the slaves they sired with slave women normal European names as an unofficial way of recognizing their paternity (since this was impossible to do legally). On Barbados for example you can identify where the master sowed his proverbial seed in plantation records by the sharply different, very normal English names that appear in a sea of novelty/abstract/weird/joke names. You'll have a long list of Graces, Fortunes, Sambos, Augustuses, Caesars etc., and then suddenly pops out Joseph Edward, William Richard, or Dorothy Elanor or something.

"Do the Japanese people believe in Shintoism?" Is kind of an annoyingly nuanced question to ask because the Japanese use Shintoism as a vehicle for so many other 'isms: environmentalism, patriotism, nationalism, exceptionalism, a long with a host of new-age spiritual and gobble-de-gook that's been seamlessly tacked on.

Some of them do. Most of the people who do though acknowledge it as a conscious cultural decision taken towards a more "uniform Japanese collective psyche/identity." The Emperor isn't *literally* divine in their eyes, but a "figurehead for the divine" a kind of Adamic man to help put a face to national spirituality, heraldry, and conscious. The Emperor's job, in turn, would be to emulate that character. He's basically a high-profile mascot.

Shintoism makes more sense if you stop thinking of it as a religion like Christianity or Buddhism where it's involved with people's spiritual goals, but a psychological religion focused on identity-based objectives. Shinto is practiced to help people feel Japanese.

The explanation is here.

https://www.isegoria.net/2014/07/iq-shredders/

The concept, basically, is that places like Hong Kong and Singapore (Japan could be included as well) are very attractive places to live in to a lot of rich expats, but they have very strict immigration policies, that screen for only the most talented people. Living in these societies, which have a strict capitalistic work ethic, are very urban and have high rent prices, in turn, discourages people from having kids. So the idea is that they are "IQ shredders", they attract some of the most qualified immigrants from around the world and then discourage them from breeding.

It points to a broader issue of how many developed nations are experiencing below replacement rates which will become a new social issue in the future. (Which as I pointed out CAN'T be solved with le hecking robots, it isn't so simple)

>>14450074
It's complicated, but here are a few factors.

1. There was a core of strong Jacobin supporters who wanted the republic and social revolution. There was also a core of strong legitimist monarchists who wanted to undo everything to do with the revolution. But most people in France just wanted reforms to make their lives better coupled with stability and order. This group was Napoleon's base. They didn't care if they had a king or a president. They didn't care if they had a Bourbon or not. They just wanted someone who could improve their lives and make France strong and secure. They supported Napoleon and did not mind when he changed his title from Consul to Emperor.

2. By the time Napoleon had made himself Emperor he was already in complete control of the government. He had been consul wielding effectively absolute power for years. This was not a complete overhaul of the way France worked, it was simply a title change and the addition of a bit more court ceremony. Since Napoleon was already in complete control, nobody could do anything about it even if they disliked it. The power of Jacobins was long since broken and everyone else was not willing to stick their neck out.

3. Ideological republicanism was a minority view, mainly centred on bourgeois intelligentsia and working-class sans-culottes. Most of France still, even post revolution was supportive or neutral to the idea of monarchism, provided their actual grievances against the old regime were addressed.

4. Napoleon deliberetely styled his monarchy differently than the old regime, "Emperor" reflects Rome and Charlemagne, not the Bourbons. He was Emperor "of the French" not "of France" implying he was leader of the people, not owner of the land. The official name of the state remained "French Republic" for years after Napoleon crowned himself. This was a new form of Revolutionary Monarchy and Napoleon was keen to emphasise the change, even if they seem to us as just wording differences.

>>14448331
He was intelligent and really hard-working and maybe, owing to some early childhood experiences and as a revolutionary, learned not to trust anyone and he developed a short-term survivalist mindset which enabled him to spend enormous reserves of mental energy on solving the Immediate Problem at hand.

People who think about revolution and building a new society can often think in grand and romanticized terms rather than the reality that you might've just gotten into this place due a historical accident and there are all all these exigent circumstances you have to deal with it. And Stalin dealt with it with extreme ruthlessness that's almost incomprehensible to me. He was basically a psycho and had no remorse or pity and did whatever he thought was necessary to industrialize the USSR, concentrate power, and he was proven right because the USSR won the war because the country had a massive industrial infrastructure to lean on.

I don't like the guy personally. The sculptor commissioned to make this statue of him in Prague shot himself after it was revealed. It was then torn down after Stalin died.

If you ask me what "Stalin" really was, though, it's the result of the 14th century and the 20th century colliding into each other and forming a dialectical synthesis. Modern socialism and the drive to industrialize combine with a guy who grew up in a part of the Russian Empire that was basically still the Middle Ages. So I don't think a lot of the brutal and remorseless stuff he did would be out of place for a 14th-century ruler, in a way he fit the conditions on Russia at the time, and his own success at powering the country forward ensured his own statues would be torn down.

Marriage fulfils three functions. Social, Religious, and Political/Economic. The religious aspect should be outside the realm of government - and if a church wants to preform a ceremony for gay couples then that's a matter for that church's leadership and congregation. The social aspect is to announce to your friends and family that you think that this relationship is the one you want to keep from now on (although given divorce stats there's some debate about how much this applies now), but again that's not something that you need a government's or church's permission for, just throw a party and announce it. The reason that marriage has legislation around it is for the last one there, the economic factor. A stable, loving, supportive heterosexual family has been proven time and time again to be the best scenario to breed and produce children (the next generation of citizens and workers, hence the government's interest in it). There isn't sufficient data to tell us how gay parents will compare to that just yet - and for such a polarising issue it is almost impossible for a fair and honest study to be conducted/published - but let's be real and acknowledge that at its best it can only be as good as a functional heterosexual marriage, just without the ability to actually breed their own children.

As such it is, in the absolute best possible case, a second rate set up for fulfilling the task of a marriage (from the perspective of the government, the people you are arguing should be involved). posts.com:
Ricky Ray Rector was the third person executed by Arkansas post-1976 for shooting and fatally wounding a Faulkner County police officer. Rector suffered brain damage afterward in a botched suicide attempt. Aside from the potential racial aspect of the black Rector shooting a white cop in a state less than 30 years from Jim Crow, the morality of executing a mentally disabled man came into question.

On March 21, 1981, Rector and three friends were planning to spend their Saturday night at Tommy's Old-Fashioned Home-Style Restaurant in Conway. One of his friends could not afford a $3 entrance fee to get into the eatery, which also featured a dance hall, and told he could not come in unless he paid. Rector became angry at this, took out a .38 revolver, and shot into the crowd gathered outside the restaurant. Two persons were wounded and a third man, Arthur Criswell, was killed.

Following the shooting, Rector took one of his friends' cars and fled the scene. He was a fugitive for three days hiding with relatives or in the woods until his sister convinced him to give himself up. He accepted, but said he would only surrender to Officer Robert Martin of the Faulkner County Sheriff's Department, a childhood acquaintance of his. Martin showed up at the house, chatted with Rector's mother and sister, and did not notice as Rector pulled a gun and fired twice into his head and neck, fatally wounding him.
posts.filename: Ricky Rector at his 1982 murder trial

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Rector then walked a few paces out into the front yard, pointed the gun to his forehead, and fired. He was discovered by other police officers unconscious but breathing. He was taken to a hospital and given emergency surgery. The .38 round went into his right frontal lobe and lodged there. Surgeons extracted the bullet. Because a relatively small portion of Rector's brain was affected, and because the shot did not cross the midline and enter both hemispheres, he would survive (ironically, the shooting was a handful of days before the attempted assassination of President Reagan, which wounded his press secretary Matthew Brady in a similar fashion).

Although he sustained a degree of cognitive impairment from the wound, he was deemed fit to stand trial and sentenced to death on two counts of first degree murder. Rector remained on Arkansas's death row for 11 years. As his execution date on January 25, 1992 drew near, Governor Bill Clinton refused to commute his sentence despite anti-death penalty advocates calling the execution of a brain damaged man cruel and unusual punishment. Clinton was then beginning his 1992 presidential campaign and advocated harsher measures against the nationwide crime epidemic.

Back when he was first elected governor in 1978, Clinton had generally opposed capital punishment and in his first term commuted the sentences of 70 death row inmates to life imprisonment. When he ran for reelection two years later, his Republican opponent Frank White charged him with being soft on crime. White defeated Clinton but the latter ran again in 1982 and recaptured the governor's seat. Clinton would be reelected thrice more, and during this stretch commuted a mere seven death sentences. Around the time he announced his presidential bid for 1992, he had greenlighted the execution of 25 persons. Clinton for his part did not publicly talk much about his views on capital punishment and preferred to avoid bringing the matter up where possible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
No one could deny that the South, in earlier days the "lynching belt" of the country, had an addiction to capital punishment and in the post-Furman era a large majority of executions in the US have been carried out by the eleven former Confederate states. "It's used a lot of times as a litmus test for executive leadership in Southern states," said Merle Black, a professor of politics and government at Emory University in Atlanta, "and I can't think of an example of a politician elected to a governorship in the South in recent years who has not been in favor of the death penalty."

Ricky Rector's attorney Jeff Rosenzweig said that it was injust and immoral to execute him due to his brain damage. "He is, in the vernacular, a zombie. His execution would be remembered as a disgrace to the state. Purely and simply, this is a measure of how civilized we are. At what level of disability do you kill people?" In any case, Rector's execution by lethal injection was carried out on schedule. He was 42 years old at his death. Ten years later, the Supreme Court ruled in Atkins v. Virginia that executing a mentally disabled person violated the 8th Amendment, although it was up to the states to define exactly what "mentally disabled" meant.

One possible hint that Rector was not "all there" came when the prison staff arrived to take him to the death chamber. He had requested a final meal and left a slice of pie behind, saying he was planning to come back and eat it later.

Some critics called Clinton's apparent pro-capital punishment stance as cynical opportunism and politicking to counteract Republican charges that Massachusetts governor Michael Dukakis had been soft on crime during his presidential campaign four years earlier. Author Christopher Hitchens called Clinton's decision to greenlight the execution "complete cynicism" and an attempt to draw attention away from the Gennifer Flowers sex scandal.

Theravada's Pali Canon is basically Vinaya (Monk rules), Suttas (sayings of Buddha) and Abhidhamma. Plus various commentaries tradition.

Vajrayana's Canon is basically Kangyur (basically Viyana/Older suttas/Sarvastivadan Abhidhammas + Mahayana only suttas + tantra suttas) + Tengyur (new tibetan only additions) + commentaries

Chinese Buddhism also has their own Vinaya/Suttas/Sarvastivadan Abhidhamma + Mahanaya suttas + tantra suttas + chinese commentaries.

This goes to the heart of how human mind creates concepts of phenomena and how/why we hold onto things conceptually in our mind. The nature of mind is something Buddhist explored greatly before the birth of Jesus Christ. Before the scientific revolution in the west took place.

The solution can be answered in many different layers. The simplest is the basic Buddhist premise. The grasping (wanting/holding/conceptualizing as permanant) of the mind is done because we're ignorant of the true reality that is changing day to day, minute by minute. So we create placeholders, hold them to the ground, in our minds, to give objects/things/people/ideas/concepts and create them out of thin air so to speak.
There are more complex/articulate answers from Buddhist themselves because this has been hotly debated within the Buddhist for thousands of years on the notion of how the mind works.

>On 30 November, the 24th was at Kunu-ri, with Chinese troops behind it. The battalion extricated itself, losing 110 troops, 30 wounded. Overall, the 24th lost one-fifth of its officers and one-third of its enlisted men in the withdrawal across the Chong'chon River.
>On 6 March, The 1/24th was re-manned and did well, moving over difficult terrain against an entrenched enemy. The 3rd Battalion initially also performed well, executing a hastily devised river crossing and advancing through rough country against well dug-in PVA troops, far from the 1st Battalion. While climbing up steep terrain, however, the 1/24th reportedly collapsed under Chinese fire and withdrew in disorder. When the Division commander learned of that action, his confidence in the 24th plummeted. Many soldiers of the 24th ran away from the fighting, tossing their weapons and equipment aside. A derisive poem throughout the U.S. Army stated: 'When the Chinaman's mortars begins to thud, the Deuce-Four Niggers begin to bug.'
>Although the 24th performed well in the attack north of the Han and the subsequent general withdrawal of the Eighth Army after the Chinese Spring Offensive of 1951, its reputation was somewhat tarnished. But it performed well in the Army's drive back north in May and June 1951. In September 1950, the 24th's division commander, Gen. William B. Kean, requested that it be disbanded because it was "untrustworthy and incapable of carrying out missions expected of an infantry regiment." By 1 October 1951, the 24th was dissolved.

I'll just look at some languages that survived and died in the Roman provinces around the Imperial period.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14449865

In the age if sword and shield battles were fought face-to-face between tightly packed blocks of soldiers whose total number was kept small by the demographics, logistical, and organizational limitations of their societies. Combat in the past was just not as complex as we would imagine today. In fact, one could argue that things actually had to be simple to work.

Ancient generals didn't have an eagle view of the battlefield. The old world was experienced from the ground level, rather than a bird's eye view. Generals would rely on live reconnaissance to report back on their surroundings. It was not uncommon for the commander themselves to get the lay of the land with his own eyes. This was the favoured approach of great generals such as Julius Caesar. Hannibal Barca spent weeks surveying the battlefield of Cannae forming a robust mental image of the future battlefield.

All of this was done without battle maps. In fact, battle maps only truly became common use with the advent of gunpowder and mass conscription and demanded more accurate cartography.

The Swedish Karolers developed a tactic called Gå-På, in which the infantry would advance quickly to within 50 yards of the enemy, give fire, advance quickly to within 20 yards of the enemy, fire one last time, and then charge. It was very much a shock tactic and they were usually still supported by pikes. It had the disadvantage if the enemy was able to pour enough fire into the formation then it would be severely depleted.

>>14450199
Bayonets weren't used until late XVII century, line formations appeared because it was easier to just handle muskets to a mass of people and make an army out of them than to employ mercenaries or pike and shot professional troops that required advanced training, years of experience and losses were thus difficult to replace. Initial linear formations however were either of defensive nature or required of higher numbers and the equivalent of human wave tactics to overwhelm traditional pike and shot elite professional troops, because unlike what morons say about innacuracy, at relatively short distances they were accurate, sniping was already a thing and a line of infantry firing at once does hit people. That was the fucking point. I mean, the retardation if it didn't... But the real game changer was artillery. Pike and shot formations had their tactics against this, like using the terrain to get some level of protection for themselves, making use of some sort of wood and metal shields and barricades, or simply ducking/lie on the ground. So even so, elite pike and shot units were still kicking the ass of linear infantry, the battle of Nordlingen is a nice example of Tercio units absolutely btfo pre-bayonet linear infantry. But then small, battlefield cannons became more available, efficient and prevalent and their firepower more overwhelming to the type of deep-ranked compact formation infantry units. It was then the combination of artillery, cavalry and easily replaceable, cost-effective large masses of infantry armed with smothbore and bayonets what altered the scenario.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Leo Tolstoy - What Then Must We Do?
posts.com:
As is said in the Bible, to man is given the law of labour, to woman the law of child- bearing. We may have changed all that with our science, but the law of the man as of the woman remains unaltered, as the liver remains in its place, and the breach of it is still inevitably punished by death.

The only difference is that the general evasion of their duty by all men would be punished by death in such a near future as may be called the present, but the evasion of the law by all women would be punished in a more distant future. The general infringement of the law by all men destroys men at once, its infringement by all women destroys the next generation; but the evasion of the law by some men and some women does not destroy the human race, but deprives the offenders of their reasonable nature as human beings.

The neglect of the law by men began long ago in those classes which could coerce others and, ever widening, it has continued till now and has reached to insanity- to an ideal of neglect of the law, to the degree expressed by Prince Blokhin and shared by Renan and the whole educated world: machines are to do the work, while people will become bundles of sybaritic nerves.

Evasion of her duty by woman used to be almost unknown. It manifested itself only in prostitution and isolated crimes of abortion. Women of the wealthy classes continued to fulfil their law when the men had ceased to perform theirs, and consequently women's influence became stronger and they continue to govern, and ought to govern, men who have infringed the law and consequently lost their reason.

It is said that women (Parisian women, especially those who are childless) have become so bewitching, utilizing all the arts of civilization, that they have mastered man by their fascinations. This is not only wrong, but is just the reverse of the case. It is not the childless woman who has mastered man, but the mother, the one who has fulfilled the law of her nature while man has neglected his.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The woman who artificially makes herself barren and bewitches man by her shoulders and curls, is not a woman mastering man but a woman who, depraved by man, has descended to his level, like him has abandoned her duty, and like him has lost every reasonable perception of life.

From this mistake has arisen that wonderful nonsense called 'women's rights'.

The formula of those rights is this: 'Ah! You, man,' says the woman, 'have violated your law of real work, and want us to bear the burden of ours. No! If that is so, then we, as well as you, can make a pretence of labour as you do, in banks, ministries, universities, academies, and studios; and like you we also wish to avail ourselves of other people's work and to live only to satisfy our lusts under pretext of a division of labour.' They say this and show in practice that they can make a pretence of work not at all worse, but even better, than men. The so-called feminist question arose, and could only arise, among men who had infringed the law of real labour.

One has only to return to that law and the feminist question cannot exist.

A woman having her special, unquestionable, and unavoidable labour, will never demand the right to share also in man's work in mines or in the ploughing field. She could demand only to share the sham labour of the wealthy classes.

The woman of our class was stronger than the man and still is stronger, not on account of her charms, not by her adroitness in making the same pharisaic pretence of work as man, but because she did not evade the law; because she bore that true labour at risk of life and with utmost effort - true labour from which the man of the wealthy classes had freed himself.

But within my own memory woman's fall her infringement of her duty-has begun, and within my memory it has spread more and more widely.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Woman, having forgotten her law, has believed that her strength lies in the fascination of her allurements, or in her dexterity in the imitation of the sham work done by men.

But children are a hindrance to both of these.

And so with the help of science (science is always ready to do anything nasty) within my memory it has come about that among the wealthy classes dozens of methods of preventing pregnancy have appeared, and appliances for preventing childbirth have become common accessories of the toilet; and so the women - mothers of the wealthy classes who held power in their hands are letting it slip in order to compete with street- women and not be outdone by them.

That evil has spread far and spreads farther every day, and soon it will have reached all the women of the wealthy classes; and then they will be on a level with the men and like them will lose every reasonable sense of life. And then for that class there will be no recovery: but there is yet time.

For all that, more women than men still fulfil their law, and so there are reasonable beings among them, and therefore some women of our class still hold in their hands the possibility of saving it.

Ah! - if those women understood their worth, their power, and used these in the work of saving their husbands, brothers, and children - saving mankind!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Women - mothers of the wealthy classes, in your hands alone is the salvation of the men of our world from the evils from which they suffer! Not those women who are occupied with their figures, bustles, coiffures, and their attractiveness for men, and who against their will, by inadvertence and in despair, bear children, and hand them over to wet- nurses ; 1 nor yet those who attend various university lectures and talk about the psychomotor centres and differentials, and who also try to avoid child-bearing in order not to hinder the stupefaction they call their 'development', - but those women and mothers who, having the power to avoid child-birth, simply and consciously submit to that eternal, immutable law, knowing that the hardship and labour of that submission is their vocation. Those are the women and mothers of our wealthy classes in whose hands, more than in any others, lies the salvation of the men of our world from the evils that oppress them. You, women and mothers, who consciously submit to the law of God, you alone in our unhappy perverted circle which has lost the semblance of being human, you alone know the whole true meaning of life according to the law of God. And you alone can by your example show men that happiness of life in submission to God's will, of which they deprive themselves. You alone know those raptures and joys, seizing your whole being, and that bliss which is ordained for man when he does not evade God's law. You know the joy of love of your husband, a joy not ending, not broken-off like all others, but forming the beginning of a new joy of love for your child. You alone, when you: are simple and submissive to God's will, know, not that farcical pretence of labour in uniforms and in illuminated halls which the men of our circle call labour, but the labour imposed on us by God, and you know the true rewards for it, the bliss it brings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You know this when after the joys of love you await with agitation, terror, and hope, that torture of pregnancy which makes you ill for nine months, brings you to the verge of death and to unbearable sufferings and pains; you know the conditions of true labour when with joy you await the approach and increase of most dreadful sufferings, after which comes the bliss known to you alone.

You know it when, directly after these sufferings, without rest, without interruption, you undertake another series of labours and sufferings - those of nursing, in which you at once forgo, and subject to your duty and your feeling the strongest human demand - that of sleep (which the proverb says is 'dearer than father or mother'), and for months and years do not have an undisturbed night's sleep, but sometimes, and often, do not sleep for whole nights together, but walk up and down with numbed arms rocking the sick child who is tearing your heart.

And when you do all this, not be lauded by anyone, not noticed by anyone, not expecting praise or reward from anyone, when you do this not as an achievement but as the labourer in the Gospel parable who came from the field, considering that you are only doing your duty - then you know what is sham fictitious labour for the praise of men, and what is real labour to fulfil God's will - the indication of which you feel in your heart.

You know that if you are a real mother it is not enough that no one sees your labour or praises you for it, but that even those for whom you have toiled will not only not thank you but will often torment and reproach you-and with the next child you will do the same: you will again suffer, again endure the unseen terrible labour, and again not expect reward from anyone, and will again feel the same satisfaction. In your hands, if you are such women, should be the influence over men, and in your hands lies their salvation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Every day your number diminishes: some occupy themselves with their fascination for men and become street-women, others are engaged in competing with men in their artificial, trifling occupations, others again who have not yet been false to their vocation, already repudiate it in their minds: they perform all the achievements of women and mothers, but accidentally, repiningly, with envy of the free, sterile women, and deprive themselves of their sole reward - the inner consciousness of the fulfilment of God's will - and instead of satisfaction, suffer from what should be their happiness.

We are so confused by our false way of life, we men of our circle have all so utterly lost the sense of life that there is no longer any distinction between us. Having shifted the whole burden and danger of life on to the backs of others, we are unable to give ourselves the true name deserved by those who compel others to perish in providing life for them,- scoundrels and cowards.

But among women there is still a difference.

There are women - human beings - women presenting the highest manifestation of a human being; and there are women - whores. And this distinction will be made by future generations, and we too cannot help making it.

Every woman, however she may dress herself and however she may call herself and however refined she may be, who refrains from child-birth without refraining from sexual relations, is a whore. And however fallen a woman may be, if she intentionally devotes herself to bearing children, she performs the best and highest service in life-fulfils the will of God-and no one ranks above her.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you are such a woman, you will not, either after two or after twenty children, say that you have borne enough, any more than a fifty-year old workman will say he has worked enough, while he still eats and sleeps and has muscles demanding work. If you are such a woman you will not shift the nursing and tending of your children on to another mother any more than a workman will let another man finish the work he has begun and nearly completed, because you put your life in that work and therefore your life is fuller and happier the more of that work you have.

And if you are such a one - and happily for men there still are such women - then that law of the fulfilment of God's will by which you guide your own life, you will apply also to your husband's life and to that of your children and of those near to you.

If you are such a one and know by your own experience that only self-sacrificing, unseen, unrewarded labour done with danger of life and uttermost effort for the life of others, is the mission of man which gives satisfaction and strength, then you will apply those same demands to others, will incite your husband to such labour, and by such labour will value and estimate people's worth, and for such labour will prepare your children.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
... She knows that children - the coming generation - are the greatest and most sacred thing it is given to man actually to see, and that to serve this holy thing with her whole being is her life.

She herself knows, being constantly between life and death and safeguarding a barely dawning life, that life and death are not her business, her business is to serve life, and therefore she will not seek distant paths for that service but will only not neglect those near at hand.

Such a mother will bear children and will nurse them herself, will first of all feed another before herself, will prepare food for the children, will sew and wash for them, will teach them and will sleep and talk with them, because she sees therein her life-work. She knows that the security of every life lies in labour and the capacity to labour, and therefore she will not seek external security in her husband's money or in her children's diplomas, but will develop in them the same capacity for a self-sacrificing fulfilment of God's will which she has felt in herself, a capacity to endure toil with expenditure and danger of life. Such a mother will not ask others what she is to do, she will know it all and will fear nothing, and will always be at peace, for she will know that she has done what she had to do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If there may be doubts for men and for a childless woman as to the way to, fulfil the will of God, for a mother that path is firmly and clearly defined, and if she fulfils it humbly with a simple heart she stands on the highest point of perfection a human being can attain, and becomes for all a model of that complete performance of God's will which all desire.

Only a mother can before her death tranquilly say to Him who sent her into this world, and Whom she has served by bearing and bringing up children whom she has loved more than herself - only she having served Him in the way appointed to her can say with tranquillity, 'Now lettest Thou Thy servant depart in peace.' And that is the highest perfection to which, as to the highest good, men aspire.

Such women who fulfil their mission reign over men, and serve as a guiding star to man- kind; such women form public opinion and prepare the coming generation; and therefore in their hands lies the highest power, the power to save men from the existing and threatening evils of our time.

Yes, women, mothers, in your hands more than in those of anyone else lies the salvation
of the world.
